text: Sabri, Lucky, thanks for joining us
at AWS Studio Mobile World Congress.
We are going to have this conversation

talking about innovation
that we have already done,

but innovation that three
players like AWS, e&,
and Ericsson we can do together.
Let me start just telling us something

about e& and these big
changes that e& is doing
from from a telco to a tech company.

Etisalat recently
rebranded its name to e&.

We operate in 16 countries
across Middle East and Africa.
We provide telecommunication services

and also digital services for
both consumer enterprises.
Okay, thank you.
And Lucky, everyone knows Ericsson,
but specifically your area,
what are you doing in terms of innovation
and the cloud adoption?

Thanks, Mauro, and thanks
for having us here.
I head up cloud and software services
in Middle East and Africa,

and essentially we are
driving ICT solutions
across the board, across the BSS/OSS

core network perspective,
the ADM IT services,

and everything that
operates across the network.

We're going through a
large period, as you know,
with the introduction of 5G

and the proliferation of
5G around our market area
with great success.

And Sabri, we did the
first project together

with Ericsson in terms
of BSS transformation
and moving some BSS workload to the cloud.
How do you think that is important

for you to have AWS and
Ericsson joining forces together
in terms of, let me say, being confident

that this kind of journey is
going in the right direction?

Well, in the past we
deployed a large multitude
of back office application in the cloud,
and it worked quite well.

It helped us to bring
world-class innovation rapidly
to our end users.
But when it comes to the telecom

critical mission applications
like the charging system,
the product catalog, and the core network,
it's very important that we verify

and test thoroughly those
application in the cloud.

So I think having AWS and
Ericsson working together

to verify these application
and to industrialize

the whole product portfolio
is extremely important.
So we see it quite positive and it serves

telecom service providers like
Etisalat or e& quite well.

And Lucky, from your point
of view, how is it important
to Ericsson on the cloud services
to have a very, very strong relationship

with AWS, joining forces to
provide the best solution
for our customers?
We are firm believers
in open architecture and infrastructure,

very much that each of
the service providers

and ecosystem players are
going to need flexibility
in the options that are made available
when it comes to infrastructure.

Many, many various
benefits from doing that.
So it's super important

that we can work with
infrastructure providers
and services providers like AWS

so that we can address e&'s
international opco requirements.
Time to market, flexibility, and coverage.

Coverage in terms of the
speed at which we can move

the software development
lifecycle, the testing lifecycle.
And at the end of the day, we really want

to make end consumers
provision those services,

use those services, and
benefit from those services
as soon as we can.
So it's immensely important.

Sabri, as you said,
Etisalat is a big group
covering 16 different countries
around Middle East and Africa,

and for sure it is not easy
to have the same strategy

and the same execution
across all the entire group.
So what is the approach that you are using

to have a solution that
doesn't fit for all the opcos,

but will allow to the group
to maintain one strategy
across the group?
Yes.
Well, we've decided to adopt a hybrid,
multi-cloud architecture
and to partner with players like AWS

where you can provide
different architecture
to fit different demands.

So like the Outpost, the
Local Zone, and the Region.

In the areas where we have
a requirement to comply
to certain data sovereignty,

Outpost is one of the architecture
that we've recommended
for our international opcos.
And also have the zone and the region,
as you're aware, in UAE, we've implemented
the Region architecture, while Local Zone
is being explored in other places.
Thank you. And Lucky,

talking about data regulation
and data sovereignty,

we know is one of the biggest
obstacles that we have
in terms of cloud adoption

and we need to find the right
balance between the regulation

and the security that
each country is requesting

and the innovation that is
driving it to move to the cloud.
How do you think that is the synthesis

between these two factors in
terms of balancing the security
and allowing the innovation to go through?
We are a firm believer, again,
in the multi-hybrid cloud concept.
And essentially, the synthesis will come
from the flexibility in the options
that we can give service providers.
The synthesis comes in the understanding
of the data sovereignty requirements.

That's why we believe
there's always going to be
some type of instance of on-premises,

and there'll always be
some type of instance
of distributing the compute storage
throughout the network as well.

And the opportunity to
work with industry players
like AWS and e& gives us the ability
to prove that it does work,

that we can cater for
regulatory requirements

around secure data, securing
the potentially subscriber data
doesn't move across borders.
But then data that's not so requirement
from a secure perspective,

then we can handle that
in the right way as well.

And I think in Egypt we did
a great proof point in that,

that we could actually
also take certain workloads

that maybe they weren't
online requirements,
maybe we could process offline,

or maybe latency wasn't
the key requirement.

So we could prove that in a
particular way using VPN, etc.

So for us, the synthesis
comes from the options

that we can give service
providers in that sense.
In Egypt, we started with the DevTest.

There were not any restriction
to verify the concept.

[Lucky] Exactly.
[Sabri] Yeah.

[Lucky] And product catalog
as well as you know.

[Mauro] We started with test
and dev that was, let me say,

a safe environment
without any, let me say,
affect detected in terms of regulation.
Where do you think that, again,

being compliant with the
regulation, we can move forward

in terms of BSS
transformation to the cloud?
And when do you think that we should stop

because we are going against
the law and the regulations?
Yeah.
I mean, basically we've decided

just to divide the BSS
landscape into different layers.
For back office application,
especially in the modules
where we don't have any sensitive data,
the idea is to move to the cloud,
to benefit from all the advanced features

and the continuous
development and enhancements.
In the area where we have the CRM,
I call it the industry generic application
like the CRM analytics, e-commerce,
we have the hybrid architecture
in which the engine and the logic,
can be in the cloud, wherever it is.

But when it comes to customer
data, it'll be on-prem
if the regulation requires it.

And then we have the
telecom specific application

like the charging and so on,
in which the requirement here
is not only being compliant,

but also ensuring the
performance and availability.
And for that one, the current partnership
between AWS and Ericsson is very helpful
to verify those applications,
and gradually, to move it to the cloud.

But some application will
continue to be on-prem
due to stringent performance requirements.
So I think it's a journey.

It needs to be gradual and I
think the rules and the law
would need to evolve gradually.
I think to Sabri's point as well,
it's not just a regulatory consideration
but very much also performance.

Certain workloads you
want to run on premises

for different reasons,
but also resilience.

You want to be able to
have resiliency options

or redundancy options that
give you flexibility also

in how you recover and
manipulate the solution
to cater for the local environment.

I think those three
together, the regulatory,

the resilience and the
performance are absolutely key
on where you want to place the workloads.

And even the cloud is
becoming more distributed.
You have this central cloud,

then you have the private,
the edge, the far edge.
So I think the technology is evolving.
[Mauro] It's evolving.
[Sabri] It's evolving.

And it'll help also to cater
for the performance requirement
and for the regulatory at the same time
Where in two years from now,
you would like to see this collaboration
between AWS and Ericsson, let me say,

landing in terms of the
journey to the cloud for you?
I think the POC that we run in Egypt,
it was a good starting point.

We'll start with the product
catalog and also the DevTest.
I think in the next two years,

we would like to see other
elements within the Ericsson BSS

moving or having the option
to be on-prem or in the cloud.

And I think that can
evolve also to include core
or the packet core in the future,
and maybe part of the radio access.
And Lucky, what do you expect
from a partner like AWS, let me say,

to evolve this partnership
in the next few years?

What should we do or
what should we do better
than today in terms of partnership?

I think we've already
started on a good footing.

So let's just say that this
was a great proof point
that when we collaborate together,

we can prove that the
technology can evolve
and it can give operators like e&
and the entire group options.
At the end of the day,

this is what we're trying
to provide business options.
What we're expecting is the same spirit,
to help us to evolve our solutions.

Ericsson's very much a
believer, I said before,
in the multi-hybrid cloud concept,

but we also write all of our
solutions, all of our software
to work on any infrastructure.

In that sense, the wealth
of knowledge and experience

that AWS has in those
deployments is absolutely crucial

for us to also learn and to
be able to cater for those
as we go through to customer environments.

And that customer
experience and the learning

that you can get from
different deployments,

but also the considerations
we talked about earlier,

the resiliency, the
performance, the security.
If we're evolving together,

if we're evolving for
specific requirements,

UAE has one particular requirement
that Egypt is different,

and then various other
countries around the region
are also having different considerations.
And I think when we work together,

we work far more effectively
to address those.

And we should be able,
let me say, to localize
and to globalize only localizing, correct?
[Sabri] Yeah.

[Mauro] So we cannot
address the entire group
just with one single approach,

but we need to identify what
are the specific requirements.

[Sabri] And to have an
extensible architecture
that can cater for different needs.
[Lucky] That's a great point.
Scaling our success is important.

I know e& and Sabri, you
are very keen to say,
if we can prove something in Egypt also,
how can you utilize it

across the rest of the
operating companies?

It's the same with our
partnership with AWS.

We love to see where else
we can scale these solutions

in a cost-effective, go-to-market
effective manner as well.

I think it's great that we
industrialize that experience.
I talk about industrialization

because that's really
when we're being able

to give the market a real
true benefit in that sense.

Sabri, we started the journey
in terms of innovation
with the project in Egypt.

There is something that we
did in terms of innovation
and something that probably we should do
in the next months and years.

What do you consider that
was the biggest innovation
that we implemented on this project

and what do you expect is
going to happen in the future?
The main thing that we did

is we deployed the
Ericsson product catalog
in AWS public cloud, basically.

It's a POC that we did,
so basically it helped

to create more innovative
service offering,
bundling telecom and non-telecom services.
And also it shortened the time to market

and it provides enhanced
operational efficiency as well.
So that's what we did so far as a POC.

We would like to extend that
to include other elements
within the Ericsson BSS portfolio.

I think together we
took a lot of learnings
out of that proof of concept.
When it comes to time to market,
reduced it by 65%, as you recall.

And then from a total cost
of ownership perspective,
I think e& was reporting 16% reduction.

And that's just on the
deployment that we made.
We saw that the benefits were there,
they could be realized.

We catered for the security
requirements by VPN usage.
We knew that there wasn't secure data
that was being transferred,

there was a particular
piece that we were proving.

So from that perspective,
we also start to understand
the regulations far deeper
and how we can cater for that as well.
I think it's safe to say

that we took a lot of learnings
also around how we set up.
[Sabri] How we created the setup, yeah.

[Lucky] Yeah, as a partnership
it worked really effectively.
But to get it going is very different

than the traditional partnerships
that we've had before.
I think just signing the agreements

took longer than the actual
proof of concept itself.

That sense, it leads to
how we should cooperate
in the future.
And the same setup can be reused
to verify other capabilities as well.
Yes.

Yeah, also, the contractual
part is part of the long journey

that we are starting and
where we are learning.
Thanks a lot for joining us.
Just for the last few words
about what is the biggest learning
that everyone should take in count
in terms of cloud adoption.
Just few words on this.
Yeah.
I think working very closely as partners
is extremely important.

Also the experimentation,
trying different things.
And to us, at least,

the benefit of cloud became
much more clearer to our opco
having elastic infrastructure,
providing the tools for the developers
to create new offering rapidly.

And also we trained some
of the software developers.

They're going through the
certification process within AWS.

For us, we realize very
clearly it is a paradigm shift.

Not necessarily just
isolated to the technology,
but also how we collaborate.

I mentioned earlier
around the contracting.

But it's also how you set
up for that complexity,

how you work through
each of those challenges.

And I think this is a great
example of a partnership
that really can realize benefits.

So we're really looking
forward to the future.
Thanks, Sabri. Thanks, Lucky.
Thanks for joining us.

[Sabri] Thank you.
[Lucky] Thank you.
